Threat hustles back to the main dining room of Spataro Restaurant & Bar, an Italian restaurant in Sacramento, California, that has been overrun by the San Antonio Spurs.

1.caption: After the Kawhi Leonard debacle that enveloped the franchise last season, the Spurs had every reason to step back in 2019. A reason why they didn't? A long-standing team culture that has served as a foundation of their success. Mark Sobhani/NBAE/Getty Images

2.caption: David Robinson, Tim Duncan, Manu Ginobili, Tony Parker and Kawhi Leonard. Twenty-two straight playoff appearances. Five championships. Throughout the eras, the Spurs have gathered for long, delicious meals, designed to bond everyone to a common goal. Andrew D. Bernstein/NBAE/Getty Images

3404956616.resolved_title: The magical day Kobe Bryant became Lord of the Rings at Rucker Park
3404956616.excerpt: ON JULY 18, 2002, Kobe Bryant approached Rucker Park, the streetball institution in Harlem. He wore a powder blue sleeveless shirt and dark shades; an oversized key-pendant swung from his chain with each step.

1.caption: When Kobe Bryant arrived at Rucker Park in 2002, the winner of three straight NBA titles, he was after something that had eluded him in his Hall of Fame career: streetball credibility. Ray Amati/NBAE/Getty Images

2.caption: Bryant won over Harlem with his high-flying but also by "changing the rhythm" of his game, according to Rucker legend "Bone Collector." Ray Amati/NBAE/Getty Images

3.caption: Bryant squared off against then-Raptors forward Jerome Williams at Rucker in July 2002; they were just two of the dozens of NBA stars who flowed through the Harlem court that summer. Ray Amati/NBAE/Getty Images

4.caption: There would be no Entertainer's Basketball Classic without visionary Greg Marius, who died of cancer in 2017. The basketball court at Rucker Park is now named after him. Bryan Bedder/Getty Images for Reebok

5.caption: Kobe's dad schooled him on the legacy of Rucker Park, where streetball legends such as Joe Hammond

7.caption: The legend of Kobe Bryant still looms over Rucker Park, even as the EBC went on hiatus due to the pandemic. Bennett Raglin/Getty Images

3802665657.excerpt: MY LATE FATHER bought me a Joe Montana jersey when I was a boy. Home red with white stripes. I don't remember when he gave it to me, or why, but I'll never forget the way the mesh sleeves felt against my arms. The last time I visited my mom, I looked for it in her closets.

1.caption: Illustration by ESPN

2.caption: Joe and Jennifer Montana, pictured in Berlin in 1991, met on the set of a razor commercial. AP Photo/Axel Kull

3.caption: George Seifert and Montana watch from the sideline during a game against the Patriots in October 1989, en route to winning back-to-back Super Bowls. Otto Greule Jr/Allsport/Getty Images

4.caption: Montana celebrates with his mother and father after the 49ers' Super Bowl win in 1982. Montana was the game's MVP. Bettmann/Getty Images

5.caption: Joe and Jennifer stand with son Nick at his Oaks Christian high school in 2009. Jacob de Golish/Getty Images

6.caption: Montana and Tom Brady stand with NFL legends Dan Marino, from left, Peyton Manning and Roger Staubach before the Super Bowl in 2020. Anthony Behar/Sipa USA

7.caption: Bruce Smith checks on Montana after he and two Bills teammates drove the QB into the ground during the AFC Championship Game with the Chiefs in 1993. DON EMMERT/AFP via Getty Images

8.caption: Montana and his best friend, Dwight Clark, were memorialized in a statue of "The Catch" outside Levi's Stadium. Peter Read Miller via AP

9.caption: "Every player in history wants to write more in the book," says Steve Young, part of the Hall of Fame quarterback fraternity that can get closest to understanding Montana's mindset. "I think about that all the time." Focus on Sport/Getty Images

2441559904.resolved_title: How a soccer agent and Chinese billionaire aimed to trade in players
2441559904.excerpt: In early 2016, Europe’s most powerful soccer agent, Jorge Mendes, stood dressed in his trademark dark suit and white shirt alongside Chinese billionaire Guo Guangchang at a luxury hotel in Shanghai.

1.caption: Agent Jorge Mendes, one of the most influential figures in European soccer, photographed at a film premiere in Leicester Square, London, in 2015. REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth

2.caption: FOOTBALL INVESTOR: Guo Guangchang, a co-founder of the Fosun group of companies and chairman of Fosun International, which is listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange. REUTERS/Rafael Marchante

3.caption: GLOBAL AMBITION: Documents show that the Fosun group aimed to create a network of football investments in Europe and beyond. Above, the logo of Fosun International. REUTERS/Bobby Yip

4.caption: POINT MAN: Nuno Espirito Santo, a former goalkeeper who helped start Jorge Mendes’ career as a soccer agent. Espirito Santo is now manager of Wolverhampton Wanderers, an English club that Mendes helped Fosun, a Chinese investment group, to buy.  Action Images via REUTERS/Paul Childs

5.caption: IN SAFE HANDS: The goalkeeper Ederson Moraes makes a save for Manchester City in 2018. Moraes was one of more than 50 players in which Gestifute, the company of agent Jorge Mendes,  owned stakes in 2015, according to Football Leaks documents. REUTERS/Andrew Yates

6.caption: CLAMPDOWN: In 2015 FIFA, the global governing body of football, changed its rules to prevent “third-party” investors buying stakes in players. Above, the logo of FIFA at its headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

7.caption: HUNGRY WOLVES: The English team Wolverhampton Wanderers, which was bought by the Chinese group Fosun in 2016, celebrate after winning the Championship in April 2018. That victory propelled them into the Premier League, the top tier of English soccer. Action Images via Reuters/Alan Walter

8.caption: GOAL ORIENTED: The financial district of Shanghai, where Fosun, an investment group hoping to expand its interests in soccer, has its main base in China. REUTERS/Aly Song
